newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian regional banks announce merger.
newsitem.headline: Australian regional banks announce merger.

text.p: Two of Australia's largest regional banks, St George Bank and Advance Bank, announced on Monday that they had agreed to merge in a deal valued at valued at A$2.65 billion (US$2.09 billion).

St George said it would offer effective A$7.30 for each Advance Bank share, equivalent to a 20-percent premium to its recent trading price. Trading in both banks' shares were halted before the announcement but Advance closed on Friday at A$6.28.

The merger appeared to be an attempt by the banks to stave off a takeover by one of the big four Australian banks which are currently prevented by monopoly laws from merging with each other and have been eyeing the smaller regional banks.

St George said Advance shareholders would be offered a combination of A$2.10 in cash, a 20-cent special cash dividend and new St George shares up to a value of A$5.00 per Advance Bank, totalling A$7.30 per share.
They would also receive an Advance Bank interim dividend, expected to be 20 cents, payable in February 1997.

"As part of the merger implementation agreement, Advance Bank has agreed to reimburse St George Bank in certain ciricumstances for costs and losses, up to A$100 million, if Advance Bank is acquired by a third party," St George added.
News that the two banks, both Sydney-based, had agreed to merge pushed up the shares of other regional banks.
Bank of Melbourne shares rose more than four percent in early trading on speculation it could be the next bid target.
